Suggest and explain why the reading is **not** 140 N

The balloon is released and it rises quickly through the atmosphere. The volume occupied by the helium increases, but the temperature of the helium may be assumed to stay constant

Fig. 4.1
A wave passes through a gap in a barrier. The wavelength of the wave is the same magnitude as the width of the gap in the barrier
Tick **one** box to indicate what happens to the wave

table.html:
diffraction and dispersion
diffraction only
dispersion only
refraction and diffraction
refraction and dispersion
refraction only

content.text: On Fig. 5.1, draw the wavefronts of the wave in the shallow water where the wave travels more slowly
The depth of the shallow water is now changed so that the speed of the wave in the shallow water is \(0.60 \text{m / s}\). The speed of the wave in the deep water is \(0.80 \text{m / s}\)
The distance between successive wavefronts in the deep water is \(1.4 \text{cm}\)
Calculate the wavelength of the wave in the shallow water
wavelength = .........
[Total: 7]
Fig. 5.1 shows six wavefronts of a wave travelling on the surface of deep water. The wave is incident on a boundary with a region where the water is shallow
The left-hand column of the table shows some possible speeds of a sound wave
In the right-hand column, write down the medium in which a sound wave has this speed
Choose from solid, liquid or gas

State, in terms of pressure, what is meant by a rarefaction
Fig. 6.1 represents a series of compressions and rarefactions of a sound wave
Astronauts set up a mirror on the Moon's surface. A laser beam is transmitted from the Earth's surface to the mirror and is then reflected back to Earth
On a certain day, the time between transmitting the beam from a point on the Earth's surface and receiving the reflected signal at the same point is 2.56 s
The speed of the laser beam is \(3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\)
Calculate the distance between the Earth's surface and the Moon's surface
distance = .........

inverted
real
same size
upright
virtual

To charge the battery, the handle is lowered so that coil Y is inside coil X
Fig. 10.1 shows the direction needed for the charging current at the battery

\(\alpha \)-particles are not suitable for the same purpose,
\(\gamma \)-rays are not suitable for the same purpose

A workman operates a machine that uses \(\beta \)-particles to determine the level of liquid in a plastic water bottle that is being filled
Suggest why
The radioactive isotope carbon-14 ( \(^{14}_{6}\mathrm {C})\) emits \(\beta \)-particles as it decays
